title: Mars Glacier
text:
Mars Glacier is a <a href="glacier">glacier</a> in the southeastern corner of <a href="Alexander%20Island">Alexander Island</a>, Antarctica, long and wide, flowing south into the <a href="George%20VI%20Ice%20Shelf">George VI Ice Shelf</a>. The glacier lies between <a href="Two%20Step%20Cliffs">Two Step Cliffs</a> and <a href="Phobos%20Ridge">Phobos Ridge</a>. Mars Glacier was first sighted from the air by <a href="Lincoln%20Ellsworth">Lincoln Ellsworth</a> on November 23, 1935, and roughly mapped from photos obtained on that flight by <a href="W.L.G.%20Joerg">W.L.G. Joerg</a>. It was first surveyed in 1949 by the <a href="Falkland%20Islands%20Dependencies%20Survey">Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey</a> and named by the <a href="UK%20Antarctic%20Place-Names%20Committee">UK Antarctic Place-Names Committee</a> for the planet <a href="Mars">Mars</a>, the fourth planet from the <a href="sun">sun</a> in the <a href="Solar%20System">Solar System</a>.
Although Mars Glacier is not located within the <a href="Planet%20Heights">Planet Heights</a> mountain range, it lies nearby, and its name derives from it, along with many other nearby glaciers and landmarks located here which are named after <a href="planet">planet</a>s, <a href="Natural%20satellite">satellites</a> and <a href="astrophysicist">astrophysicist</a>s.
